newsitem.title: FRANCE: Business seen rising in coming months-BoF survey.
newsitem.headline: Business seen rising in coming months-BoF survey.

text.p: French industrialists expect activity to increase in all sectors in the coming months except the car sector, where business is expected to stabilise, the Bank of France's monthly survey showed.

Business leaders said industrial activity had recovered in June, the BoF reported. There were significant pick-ups in consumer goods and semi-finished goods, and more moderate rises in industrial capital goods.
Output stabilised in agribusiness and fell slightly in the car sector.
Capacity use improved. Overall demand firmed both on export markets and in the domestic market, partly helped by stock-building.
Order books appeared to be generally satisfying. Stocks rose in consumer goods, the car sector and agribusiness.
"During the next few months, activity should increase in all sectors, except the car sector where it is expected to stabilise," the Bank of France said in a statement.
"Prices of commodities and finished products did not change much overall," the Bank said.
"Some increases in the cost of supplies were seen in some semi-finished goods sectors, caused mainly by the rise in the dollar. These were not passed on into sale prices," it said.
Business leaders remained cautious as regards investment, and little investment spending had been undertaken.
Commercial activity, which had been strong in May, fell in June, partly because of the weather. It was up overall over the two-month period.
In building and public works, there had been a mainly seasonal recovery in the second quarter of 1997.
The total number of employees remained stable in industry, except for the car industry where numbers fell again. Numbers also fell in the building sector, commerce and market sector services.
